last night's events in Rio dashed any
hopes the authorities may have had that
the protest movement was losing impetus
ahead of the forthcoming World Cup you
see spending on the cup and things we
don't need rather than health education
and decent transport she says led by the
hardcore group known as the black bloc's
hundreds of demonstrators descended on
the Central Terminal denouncing plans to
raise the price of public transport with
millions of pounds of public money being
spent on World Cup stadiums protesters
cry was FIFA pay my fair but events soon
descended into violence and the running
battle between riot police and
demonstrators for several weeks a month
this is the Central Station in the heart
of the city and it is ostensibly a
protest against rising prices in public
thousands of protesters have marched in
hell from the Central Station when
they've been met by riot police with T
gas and smoke bombs and the situation is
desperate violent hundreds of anxious
commuters were caught between the two
sides as the confined space filled with
tear gas the clashes spilled outside the
front line
Rio's Main Avenue at rush hour as what
appears to be a homemade device explodes
a journalist forced to the floor first
to help my cameraman and I tried to stop
the bleeding from a gaping wound to
Santiago and Rogers head amid frantic
scenes protesters blamed police for the
attack but it quite possibly came from
the other side six minutes later we
managed to get the photojournalist to
hospital still alive but in a critical
condition but even as the car speeds off
the clashes resume proof that these anti
worldcup anti-government protests have
not relented and may even have gained
fresh momentum where Davis BBC News Rio
de Janeiro
